selected_quotes: Cells grown from biopsies from older Type 2 diabetes patients show persistent abnormalities #PubMedCrawl

citation.abstract: Objective: Few methods enable molecular and cellular studies of vascular aging or type-2 diabetes (T2D). Here we report a new approach to studying human vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) pathophysiology by examining VSMCs differentiated from progenitors found in skin. Approach and Results: Skin-derived precursors (SKPs) were cultured from biopsies (N=164, ~1 cm(2)) taken from the edges of surgical incisions of older adults (N=158; males 72%; mean age 62.7±13 years) undergoing cardiothoracic surgery, and differentiated into VSMCs at high efficiency (>80% yield).  The number of SKPs isolated from subjects with T2D were ~50% lower than those without T2D (cells/g: 0.18±0.03, N=58 vs. 0.40±0.05, N=100, P<0.05).  Importantly, SKP-derived VSMCs from subjects with T2D had higher Fluo-5F-determined baseline cytosolic Ca(2+) concentrations (AU: 1,968±160, N=7, vs. 1,386±170, N=13, P<0.05), and a trend towards greater Ca(2+) cycling responses to norepinephrine (AUC: 177,207±24,669, N=7 vs. 101,537±15,881, N=20, P<0.08) despite a reduced frequency of Ca(2+) cycling (events s(-1) cell(-1): 0.011±0.004, N=8 vs. 0.021±0.003, N=19, P<0.05) than those without T2D.  SKP-derived VSMCs from subjects with T2D also manifest enhanced sensitivity to phenylephrine in an impedance-based assay (EC50 nM: 72.3±63.6, N=5 vs. 3,684±3,122, N=9, P<0.05), and impaired wound closure in vitro (% closure: 21.9±3.6, N=4 vs. 67.0±10.3, N=4, P<0.05).  Compared to aortic- and saphenous vein-derived primary VSMCs, SKP-derived VSMCs are functionally distinct, but mirror defects of T2D also exhibited by primary VSMCs.  Conclusion: Skin biopsies from older adults yield sufficient SKPs to differentiate VSMCs, which reveal abnormal phenotypes of T2D that survive differentiation and persist even after long-term normoglycemic culture.
citation.title: Skin-derived precursors from human subjects with type-2 diabetes yield dysfunctional vascular smooth muscle cells.
